answersResultList.title: Trichophobia (or fear of loose hairs)
answersResultList.resultContent: You're on the lookout for unattached hairs or shedding scalps. You fear invisible strands tripping you, bringing others down with you, and knotting your limbs together. You can't stop thinking about loose hairs getting too close to your face or neck, and can't resist removing them from other's clothing. For sanity's sake, avoid that packaged convenience food. You never know what might get between two pieces of bread.

answersResultList.title: Scopophobia (or fear of being looked at)
answersResultList.resultContent: You take shy to a whole new level. You feel the weight of judgment in other people's glances. Your body language criminally betrays your sensory pleasure when smelling or tasting. Eating something potentially messy in public would be torture, considering the high risk for stains or smears. Your clothing is your last line of defense against the horror of public nudity. There are medications that could help.

answersResultList.title: Arachibutyrophobia (or fear of peanut butter sticking to the roof of one's mouth)
answersResultList.resultContent: Your acute sense of touch has you recoiling from the sticky or clammy, although the mere thought of melted or mushy anything fusing to your palate sends you into fugue state. Even singing a song you're ashamed to admit you love reminds you of how the family dog yelped when you fed her peanut butter as a child. Try to remain calm.

answersResultList.title: Nomophobia (or fear of being disconnected from the rest of the world without mobile phone access)
answersResultList.resultContent: You're an auditory person, and the world sounds best through a tiny cell phone speaker. Actually, that's the only way the world makes sense. Without that cell, you feel like just another stinky, unkempt organism wandering the planet's surface. Crunchy foods, especially salty snacks, remind you of signals breaking up. Talking face to face with a therapist could help you.
